member.name: T:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventCallback
member.summary: IIviEventCallback Interface

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventCallback.EventCallback(Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventEntry)
member.summary: Implemented by a sink client. The event server calls this routine when an event occurs which the sink client wants to recieve.
member.param: Contains full information about the incoming event.

member.name: T:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry
member.summary: IIviEventEntry Interface

member.name: T:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventEntry
member.summary: Same as IIviEventEntry Interface

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry.ConfigureLocation(System.String,System.Int32,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Configures the location attributes of an event.
member.param: The name of the host machine. If NULL or empty string is specified as input, then the host name will be automatically generated by the Event Server In Proc.
The ID of the process that the event belongs to. If a value of zero or less is specified, then it will be automatically generated by the Event Server In Proc.
The name of the subsystem that the event belongs to.
The name of the role that the event belongs to.
The name of the source that the event belongs to.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry.SetInfo(System.String[]@)
member.summary: Set the extra information of the event. SetInfo and GetInfo are intentionally not made into properties because of problems related to SAFEARRAYs in Visual Basic.
member.param: The "infos" parameter specifies extra information of the event. If the "description" contains one or more "%s" strings, the FormatEventEntry method in I, attempts to insert the array of extra information at those locations. Otherwise the "infos" is simply appended at the end of the description. This parameter can be NULL or empty which means there is no extra information carried with this event.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry.GetInfo
member.summary: Get the extra information carried with an event entry. SetInfo and GetInfo are intentionally not made into properties because of problems related to SAFEARRAYs in Visual Basic.
member.returns: An array of "infos" passed to SetInfo.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry.FormatEventEntry
member.summary: This function returns the event as a formatted text string. The string will include all the information carried with the event entry.

member.name: P:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry.TimeStamp
member.summary: The timestamp of an event. The timestamp includes hours, minutes, and seconds. To set/get the number of nanoseconds, use the property "Nanoseconds".

member.name: P:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry.Nanoseconds
member.summary: The nanoseconds portion of the timestamp for an event.

member.name: P:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry.Description
member.summary: The description of an event.

member.summary: The select code definition is currently the same as the Event Type.

member.name: P:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry.EventCode
member.summary: The event code for an event.

member.name: P:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry.EventType
member.summary: One of the values defined by IviEventServerEventTypeEnum.

member.name: P:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry.HostName
member.summary: The host machine name of the event.

member.name: P:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventEntry.ProcessId

member.name: T:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventSource
member.summary: IIviEventSource Interface

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventSource.EventLevelChanged(System.String,System.Int32,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Implemented by a source client which wishes to receive event level control from its sink clients. When a sink requests an event level change through ChangeMySourceEventLevel(), the Event Server invokes this function.
member.param: The host name of the sink.
The process ID of the sink.
The subsystem name of the sink.
The role name of the sink.
The view name of the sink.
Which types of events the sink client wants the source to send.

member.name: T:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventServer
member.summary: IIviEventServer Interface

member.name: T:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerDLL
member.summary: Same as IIviEventServer Interface
A source calls this function to connect itself to the Event Server.
member.param: A source that wishes to receive event level change notifications can pass its IIviEventSource interface; otherwise, this parameter is passed in as NULL.
The name of the host machine. If NULL or empty string is specified as input, then the host name will be automatically generated by the Event Server In Proc.
The ID of the process that the source client belongs to. If a value of zero or less is specified, then it will be automatically generated by the Event Server In Proc.
The name of the subsystem that the source client belongs to, e.g.,"This Measurement Subsystem".
The name of the role that the source client belongs to, e.g.," Spectrum Analyzer".
The name of the source client, e.g., "This Spectrum Analyzer".

A source can overwrite the default settings for certain events. This parameter is an array of events or masked events. The "events" parameter does not represent all the events that the source will send, rather, it represents the events for which the source wants to overwrite the default settings. See Compliance Notes for the default settings. To specify the preferences, the "events" parameter can be an array of single events, or it could be an array of "masked" events. Events are masked by specifying the event code as zero and by specifying the select code as IviEventServerStatus, IviEventServerEvent, IviEventServerWarning, IviEventServerError, or IviEventServerDebug. If NULLs are provided for this parameter or the size of the array is zero, then it means that the source accepts all the default settings. Accepting all default settings is a common use case.

This is an array of latency settings corresponding to the "events" array. If NULLs are provided for this parameter or the size of the array is zero, then it means that the source accepts all the default settings.

This array also corresponds to the "events" array. This will determine whether the Event Server will sort the events or not. If NULLs are provided for this parameter or the size of the array is zero, then it means that the source accepts all the default settings.

This array also corresponds to the "events" array. This will determine whether the Event Server will persist the events or not. If NULLs are provided for this parameter or the size of the array is zero, then it means that the source accepts all the default settings.

If 0, the event server gives back a new cookie to the source to identify this connection. If nonzero, the event server will try to replace the setting of an existing connection with the new settings. If this fails, the server will treat it as a new connection.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventServer.ConnectSink(System.Object,System.String,System.Int32,System.String,System.String,System.String,Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventEntry[]@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Before a sink can receive an event, it must call this function to connect itself to the Event Server. With this function, the sink client passes its own location information to the Event Server and also specifies its interested events.
member.param: A sink client must implement either IIviEventCallback or IIviEventCallbackFast interface for receiving callbacks. The client supplies its IUnknown interface. The server will do a QueryInterface to find out if it is an IIviEventCallback or IIviEventCallbackFast interface. The Event Server will favor the faster IIviEventCallbackFast if the client implements both interfaces.
The name of the host machine. If NULL or empty string is specified as input, then the host name will be automatically generated by the Event Server In Proc.
The ID of the process that the sink client belongs to. If a value of zero or less is specified, then it will be automatically generated by the Event Server In Proc.
The name of the subsystem that the sink client belongs to, e.g., "This Receive Subsystem".
The name of the role that the sink client belongs to, e.g., "Measurement Server".
The name of the sink client, e.g., "This Measurement Server".

A sink can provide an array of events that it is interested in. Each IIviEventEntry interface pointer of the "interestedEvents" array represents an event or a masked event. Specifying NULL or providing an empty array means that the sink client wishes to receive all events. To specify its interests, the "interestedEvents" parameter can be an array of single events, or it could be an array of "masked" events. Currently allowed masks are any of the location information: host name, process ID, subsystem name, role name or view name. As an example, specifying NULL, empty string or "*" for the role name means it is interested in all events as long as the host name, process ID, and subsystem name match. Specifying subsystem name as NULL, empty string, or "*" means it is interested in all events as long as the host name and process ID of the source matches. Specifying 0 for process ID means it is interested in all events as long as the host name matches. Masks may also include the description field and the select code. The order of comparison from first to last is: host name, process ID, subsystem name, role name, view name, select code, event code, description.

If (*sinkCookie) is 0, the Server gives back a cookie to identify this connection, otherwise the server will try to replace the setting of an existing connection with the new settings. If this fails, the server will treat it as a new connection.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventServer.DisconnectSource(System.Int32)
member.summary: A source client (or a source and sink client) calls this function when it has finished using the Event Server and before the client exits.
member.param: The source connection identified by this cookie is torn down and cleaned up.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventServer.DisconnectSink(System.Int32)
member.summary: A sink client (or a source and sink client) calls this function when it has finished using the Event Server and before the client exits.
member.param: The sink connection identified by this cookie is torn down and cleaned up.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventServer.SendEvent(System.Int32,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: A source uses this function to send an event. This is the fast way to send an event with minimal information.
member.param: This is a numeric code for the event. The Event Server attempts to interpret this code as an HRESULT. The most significant bit will be translated and converted to either IviEventServerStatus (when the bit is 0) or IviEventServerError (when the bit is 1). The select code will contain this converted value. To send other types of events, a client uses SendEventEx.
This is a text description of the event. The string can be empty.
This identifies the source connection.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventServer.SendEventEx(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String,System.String[]@,System.Int32)
member.summary: A source uses this function to send an event. This is a slower version of SendEvent since it carries more information.
member.param: This is the select code of the event. If the specified select code does not match any of the defined values, the most significant bit of EventCode will be translated and converted to either IviEventServerStatus (when the bit is 0) or IviEventServerError (when the bit is 1).
The numeric code for the event.
This is a text description of the event. The string can be empty.

The "infos" parameter specifies extra information of the event.If the "description" contains one or more "%s" strings, the FormatEventEntry method in IiviEventEntry attempts to insert the array of extra information at those locations. Otherwise, the "infos" is simply appended at the end of the description. This parameter can be NULL or empty which means there is no extra information carried with this event.
This identifies the source connection.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventServer.GetNextEvent(System.Int32@)
member.summary: A client uses this interface function to retrieve the next event that has already been persisted.
member.param: This value uniquely identifies every event that is stored in the log file. To get the first event, a client passes in zero as (*EID). The server returns the first event in the log file and updates the returned value of (*EID) to uniquely identify the subsequent event in the log file. Thus by calling this interface function in a loop and passing in an initial value of zero, a client can traverse the entire length of the log file from the first event to the last. After the last event is retrieved, (*EID) is set to zero again and the first event is returned.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventServer.GetPreviousEvent(System.Int32@)
member.summary: A client uses this interface function to retrieve the previous event that has already been persisted. This function is the reverse of GetNextEvent.
member.param: This value uniquely identifies every event that is stored in the log file. To get the first event, a client passes in zero as (*EID). The server returns the first event in the log file and updates the returned value of (*EID) to uniquely identify the subsequent event in the log file. Thus by calling this interface function in a loop and passing in an initial value of zero, a client can traverse the entire length of the log file from the first event to the last. After the last event is retrieved, (*EID) is set to zero again and the first event is returned.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventServer.ChangeMySourceEventLevel(System.Int32,Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLevelVectorEnum)
member.summary: A sink client uses this function to inform its sources the types of events that they should be sending. A source can ignore this command, since there is nothing enforced by the Event Server. The Event Server will send this change request via the IIviEventSource interface of the source client if it exists.
member.param: This identifies the sink connection.
Different levels of events.

member.name: T:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventManager
member.summary: IIviEventManager Interface

member.param: The host names for all sources.

The subsytem names for all sources.
The role names for all sources.
The view names for all sources.
The cookies for all source connections.

member.summary: Used by an Event Manager client to query all the existing sink connections in the system. Each sink is identified by location information supplied at the client connection time. The array of cookies further uniquely identifies the connections.
member.param: The host names for all sources.
The Process IDs for all sources.
The subsytem names for all sources.
The role names for all sources.
The view names for all sources.
The cookies for all sink connections.

member.summary: Used by an Event Manager client to query the preference settings of a particular source connection.
member.param: Identifies the source.
The same array of events passed to ConnectSource.
The same array of latencies passed to ConnectSource.
The same array of orders passed to ConnectSource.
The same array of logs passed to ConnectSource.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventManager.GetEventSinkInfo(System.Int32,Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventEntry[]@)
member.summary: Used by an event manager client to query the interested events of a particular sink connection.
member.param: Identifies the sink.
The same array of events passed to ConnectSource.

member.summary: Used by an event manager client to change the preference settings of a particular source connection.
member.param: Idendifies the source.
The same array of events passed to ConnectSource.
The same array of latencies passed to ConnectSource.
The same array of orders passed to ConnectSource.
The same array of logs passed to ConnectSource.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IIviEventManager.SetEventSinkInfo(System.Int32,Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventEntry[]@)
member.summary: Used by an event manager client to change the interests of a particular sink connection.
member.param: Identifies the sink.
The same array of events passed to ConnectSource.

member.name: T:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerDLLClass
member.summary: IviEventServerDLL object

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerDLLClass.#ctor
member.summary: IviEventServerDLL object constructor
A source calls this function to connect itself to the Event Server.
member.param: A source that wishes to receive event level change notifications can pass its IIviEventSource interface; otherwise, this parameter is passed in as NULL.
The name of the host machine. If NULL or empty string is specified as input, then the host name will be automatically generated by the Event Server In Proc.
The ID of the process that the source client belongs to. If a value of zero or less is specified, then it will be automatically generated by the Event Server In Proc.
The name of the subsystem that the source client belongs to, e.g.,"This Measurement Subsystem".
The name of the role that the source client belongs to, e.g.," Spectrum Analyzer".
The name of the source client, e.g., "This Spectrum Analyzer".

A source can overwrite the default settings for certain events. This parameter is an array of events or masked events. The "events" parameter does not represent all the events that the source will send, rather, it represents the events for which the source wants to overwrite the default settings. See Compliance Notes for the default settings. To specify the preferences, the "events" parameter can be an array of single events, or it could be an array of "masked" events. Events are masked by specifying the event code as zero and by specifying the select code as IviEventServerStatus, IviEventServerEvent, IviEventServerWarning, IviEventServerError, or IviEventServerDebug. If NULLs are provided for this parameter or the size of the array is zero, then it means that the source accepts all the default settings. Accepting all default settings is a common use case.

This is an array of latency settings corresponding to the "events" array. If NULLs are provided for this parameter or the size of the array is zero, then it means that the source accepts all the default settings.

This array also corresponds to the "events" array. This will determine whether the Event Server will sort the events or not. If NULLs are provided for this parameter or the size of the array is zero, then it means that the source accepts all the default settings.

This array also corresponds to the "events" array. This will determine whether the Event Server will persist the events or not. If NULLs are provided for this parameter or the size of the array is zero, then it means that the source accepts all the default settings.

If 0, the event server gives back a new cookie to the source to identify this connection. If nonzero, the event server will try to replace the setting of an existing connection with the new settings. If this fails, the server will treat it as a new connection.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerDLLClass.ConnectSink(System.Object,System.String,System.Int32,System.String,System.String,System.String,Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventEntry[]@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Before a sink can receive an event, it must call this function to connect itself to the Event Server. With this function, the sink client passes its own location information to the Event Server and also specifies its interested events.
member.param: A sink client must implement either IIviEventCallback or IIviEventCallbackFast interface for receiving callbacks. The client supplies its IUnknown interface. The server will do a QueryInterface to find out if it is an IIviEventCallback or IIviEventCallbackFast interface. The Event Server will favor the faster IIviEventCallbackFast if the client implements both interfaces.
The name of the host machine. If NULL or empty string is specified as input, then the host name will be automatically generated by the Event Server In Proc.
The ID of the process that the sink client belongs to. If a value of zero or less is specified, then it will be automatically generated by the Event Server In Proc.
The name of the subsystem that the sink client belongs to, e.g., "This Receive Subsystem".
The name of the role that the sink client belongs to, e.g., "Measurement Server".
The name of the sink client, e.g., "This Measurement Server".

A sink can provide an array of events that it is interested in. Each IIviEventEntry interface pointer of the "interestedEvents" array represents an event or a masked event. Specifying NULL or providing an empty array means that the sink client wishes to receive all events. To specify its interests, the "interestedEvents" parameter can be an array of single events, or it could be an array of "masked" events. Currently allowed masks are any of the location information: host name, process ID, subsystem name, role name or view name. As an example, specifying NULL, empty string or "*" for the role name means it is interested in all events as long as the host name, process ID, and subsystem name match. Specifying subsystem name as NULL, empty string, or "*" means it is interested in all events as long as the host name and process ID of the source matches. Specifying 0 for process ID means it is interested in all events as long as the host name matches. Masks may also include the description field and the select code. The order of comparison from first to last is: host name, process ID, subsystem name, role name, view name, select code, event code, description.

If (*sinkCookie) is 0, the Server gives back a cookie to identify this connection, otherwise the server will try to replace the setting of an existing connection with the new settings. If this fails, the server will treat it as a new connection.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerDLLClass.SendEvent(System.Int32,System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: A source uses this function to send an event. This is the fast way to send an event with minimal information.
member.param: This is a numeric code for the event. The Event Server attempts to interpret this code as an HRESULT. The most significant bit will be translated and converted to either IviEventServerStatus (when the bit is 0) or IviEventServerError (when the bit is 1). The select code will contain this converted value. To send other types of events, a client uses SendEventEx.
This is a text description of the event. The string can be empty.
This identifies the source connection.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerDLLClass.SendEventEx(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.String,System.String[]@,System.Int32)
member.summary: A source uses this function to send an event. This is a slower version of SendEvent since it carries more information.
member.param: This is the select code of the event. If the specified select code does not match any of the defined values, the most significant bit of EventCode will be translated and converted to either IviEventServerStatus (when the bit is 0) or IviEventServerError (when the bit is 1).
The numeric code for the event.
This is a text description of the event. The string can be empty.

The "infos" parameter specifies extra information of the event.If the "description" contains one or more "%s" strings, the FormatEventEntry method in IiviEventEntry attempts to insert the array of extra information at those locations. Otherwise, the "infos" is simply appended at the end of the description. This parameter can be NULL or empty which means there is no extra information carried with this event.
This identifies the source connection.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerDLLClass.GetNextEvent(System.Int32@)
member.summary: A client uses this interface function to retrieve the next event that has already been persisted.
member.param: This value uniquely identifies every event that is stored in the log file. To get the first event, a client passes in zero as (*EID). The server returns the first event in the log file and updates the returned value of (*EID) to uniquely identify the subsequent event in the log file. Thus by calling this interface function in a loop and passing in an initial value of zero, a client can traverse the entire length of the log file from the first event to the last. After the last event is retrieved, (*EID) is set to zero again and the first event is returned.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerDLLClass.GetPreviousEvent(System.Int32@)
member.summary: A client uses this interface function to retrieve the previous event that has already been persisted. This function is the reverse of GetNextEvent.
member.param: This value uniquely identifies every event that is stored in the log file. To get the first event, a client passes in zero as (*EID). The server returns the first event in the log file and updates the returned value of (*EID) to uniquely identify the subsequent event in the log file. Thus by calling this interface function in a loop and passing in an initial value of zero, a client can traverse the entire length of the log file from the first event to the last. After the last event is retrieved, (*EID) is set to zero again and the first event is returned.

member.name: M:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerDLLClass.ChangeMySourceEventLevel(System.Int32,Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLevelVectorEnum)
member.summary: A sink client uses this function to inform its sources the types of events that they should be sending. A source can ignore this command, since there is nothing enforced by the Event Server. The Event Server will send this change request via the IIviEventSource interface of the source client if it exists.
member.param: This identifies the sink connection.
Different levels of events.

member.param: The host names for all sources.

The role names for all sources.
The view names for all sources.
The cookies for all source connections.

member.name: T:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerEventTypeEnum
member.summary: Ivi Event Server Event Type Enum

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerEventTypeEnum.IviEventServerEventTypeStatus
member.summary: Events that indicate the status of an operation when there is no error condition, for example, an "operation completed" event is a status event.

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerEventTypeEnum.IviEventServerEventTypeEvent
member.summary: Events that are time-critical. For example, a trigger event.

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerEventTypeEnum.IviEventServerEventTypeWarning
member.summary: Events that indicate warning conditions, for example, a "parameter out of range" event could be a warning event.

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerEventTypeEnum.IviEventServerEventTypeError
member.summary: Events that indicate error conditions, for example, an "operation failed" event is an error event.

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerEventTypeEnum.IviEventServerEventTypeDebug
member.summary: Events for debugging purposes, for example, traces inserted by the developers.

member.name: T:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLatencyEnum
member.summary: Ivi Event Server Latency Enum

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLatencyEnum.IviEventServerLatencyLow
member.summary: Events with latency setting of IviEventServerLatencyLow will be sent first when the server is running low on internal cache space.

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLatencyEnum.IviEventServerLatencyMedium
member.summary: When the server is running low on internal cache space, events with latency settings of IviEventServerLatencyMedium will be sent after all the events with IviEventServerLatencyLow have been sent.

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLatencyEnum.IviEventServerLatencyHigh
member.summary: When the server is running low on internal cache space, events with latency settings of IviEventServerLatencyHigh will be sent after all other events have been sent.

member.name: T:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLevelVectorEnum
member.summary: Ivi Event Server Level Vector Enum

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLevelVectorEnum.IviEventServerLevelVectorStatus
member.summary: This bit indicates whether to send the status events.

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLevelVectorEnum.IviEventServerLevelVectorEvent
member.summary: This bit indicates whether to send the event events.

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLevelVectorEnum.IviEventServerLevelVectorWarning
member.summary: This bit indicates whether to send the warning events.

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLevelVectorEnum.IviEventServerLevelVectorError
member.summary: This bit indicates whether to send the error events.

member.name: F:Ivi.EventServer.Interop.IviEventServerLevelVectorEnum.IviEventServerLevelVectorDebug
member.summary: This bit indicates whether to send the debug events.
